awd_titl_txt: Developing Science Leaders in High-Need Elementary Schools: Noyce Master Teaching Fellows Academy
awd_abstract_narration:
This Noyce Track 3: Master Teaching Fellowships (MTF) project, Developing Science Leaders in High-Need Elementary Schools: Noyce Master Teaching Fellows Academy, will address a serious gap in the STEM knowledge pipeline - the dearth of strong science instruction.  The project aims to increase understanding of factors that contribute to building  a foundation for science learning in the critical elementary school years by providing elementary teachers who teach in underperforming, high-poverty schools with 1) the disciplinary and pedagogical knowledge to more effectively engage students in science learning and achievement and 2) the leadership skills to develop powerful professional learning communities that can support and sustain improved elementary science instruction.  The National Science Teachers Association (NSTA) observed that learning science is a cumulative process, requiring strong groundwork to be laid in childhood.  Because relatively few initiatives focus on elementary level STEM instruction, this project provides a bellwether opportunity to accumulate and disseminate unique knowledge about best practices for improved elementary science education. Project results will not only shape effective strategies for improving science teaching and learning across New York City classrooms, schools, and districts, but also serve as a national model for driving better STEM outcomes through the enhancement of elementary STEM education. 

This College of Staten Island (CSI) Master Teaching Fellowships Noyce project will recruit 16 K-5 experienced and exemplary elementary teachers working in high-need, low performing schools in New York City's District 31 and prepare them to become science teacher leaders in this District.  The project, in partnership with the non-profit Staten Island MakerSpace, will enable these elementary teachers to advance their science teaching while, simultaneously, facilitating development of leadership skills to create a network of science teacher leaders with the collective capacity to improve the quality of science teaching across the district's high-need elementary schools.  To build these competencies, the project will engage teachers in a blended, multi-component Professional Development (PD) that includes: a) content-based graduate level courses at CSI with integrated STEM research/lab experiences on campus, led by CSI STEM faculty; b) face-to-face training led by CSI School of Education faculty and Discovery Institute experts in the fields of teacher leadership, curriculum, and pedagogy; and c) online and face-to-face collaboration with project faculty and MTF peers. The PD will also include a school and field-based component that is integrated into the daily work of participating teachers by involving them in delivering workshops in STEM learning and teaching to colleagues at their own schools and at the Staten Island MakerSpace. By focusing on teachers' development in three overlapping waves - teacher as science learner, teacher as science teacher, and teacher as facilitator of professional community - the project will develop educators' capacity to affect their individual classrooms and schools as well as district-wide science instruction.

por.por_cntn:
"Developing Science Leaders in High-Need Elementary Schools: Noyce Master Teaching Fellows Academy" aims to develop science/ STEM teacher leaders in high-need elementary schools in District 31 of New York City. For this purpose, the project's recruited 16 experienced elementary school teachers from high-need public schools on Staten Island and Brooklyn to deepen their science content knowledge and to develop their leadership skills through custom-designed academic courses, professional development, and opportunities to guide instruction in their schools. By providing rich and targeted learning opportunities for teachers, the project aims to transform teaching to provide all students access to high-quality science instruction. It is equally important not only to deepen New York City's teachers' pedagogical and science content knowledge but also to equip teachers with the skills and knowledge to act as teacher-leaders who can spearhead the improvement of science education in elementary schools across the city. The fundamental goal of this project was to build a solid underpinning for science learning in the elementary grades, which will set students up for success in science during middle and high school and beyond.

In spite of the severed disruption that COVID caused, the program produced observed improvements in science instruction: We have two indirect ways to measure the improvement of science instruction. Instead of science class observations, we used the school administrators' observations. The second measure comes from looking at each MTF student's science achievement. Improvement in students implies improvement in instruction. The MTFs' abilities to facilitate communicative interactions with their students showed strong growth, and their abilities to foster relationships with their students showed the same results. The MTFs' abilities to design and implement inquiry-based lessons grew very strongly, still leaving room for improvement. Their propositional content knowledge grew, although their procedural content knowledge did not, both having room for improvement. The MTFs' students themselves showed significant improvements in their science content knowledge.

We observed that changes in students' grades correlated strongly with both final and average scores in the:

■ Knowledge of Content

■ Engagement with Students in Learning

■ Creating an Environment of Respect and Rapport with the strongest correlation related to:

■ Demonstrating Knowledge of Content and Pedagogy      

■ Designing Coherent Instruction

■ Managing Student Behavior

■ Engaging Students in Learning

The program also led to the creation of MTFs' professional learning communities, as evidenced by online and face-to-face collaboration in the graduate courses and outside the college classroom. The teachers shared resources, professional development opportunities, and ideas regularly. This PLC is the core of the district's future network of science elementary school teachers.

The program observed improved PD instruction focused on leadership and facilitated shared dialogue between the MTFs. Half of our MTFs reported taking on leadership positions within their schools, where they took on either STEM-related teacher trainers or lead teacher functions of various programs. In these leadership roles, they can implement strategies learned in different PDs, such as adult learning, distance learning, teacher leadership, and instructional improvement. 

Impact:

The graduate course developed within the project will be available to the School of Education to promote a better understanding of science as a discipline by graduate students preparing to become elementary school teachers. The course affected the way MTFs teach science in their schools, as demonstrated by the collected videos of teaching, MTFs feedback, and course evaluations. Therefore, we expect the impact on MTF students' science learning because of improved science instruction by the MTFs.

Seven professional development workshops focused on effective teaching and learning elementary science and provided MTFs with valuable resources for their science classrooms. The MTFs already implemented the knowledge and skills gained in these workshops in their classrooms and have affected how they teach science. Some MTFs teach coding as part of their teaching assignments in schools. Based on a workshop that introduced MTFs to the foundations of coding and its role in STEM, MTFs found more connections between coding, science, and mathematics, which affected how they started teaching coding to their students.

This proposal aimed initially at preparing Elementary School Master Teaching Fellows through the development of conceptual understanding, enriching science content, and performance-based assessment. By changing the pedagogical approach to science teaching, MTFs can enhance students' learning of the standards-based science curriculum and meet the need of children with different learning abilities. The project trained the MTFs to engage their students in project-based learning through an open-ended scientific question. This approach allows students to engage in learning and to bring a different perspective to the conversation based on their understanding of the topic. This pedagogical method significantly bifurcates from the classical scripted, teacher-centered content delivery and allows students to be part of the learning process.
